climbs.name: Trendy Bendy
climbs.fa: Greg Barnes, Julie Haas, Florence Scholl, July 2007.

content.description: Knobby sport route with fun movement, but less than stellar rock quality. We waffled between 5.9 and 10a on the rating, and went with the higher one figuring knobs might break over time!
content.location: Just to the right of the right-leaning corner about 200' right of The Block. See photo for Aileron.

content.description: A cool sport climb that deserves more traffic.  Well bolted by Tuolumne standards.  Some powerful moves off the ground lead to balancy climbing above.
content.protection: 5 quickdraws plus 2 for the anchor.  Lower/rap off rings.
content.location: A few hundred feet downhill of the "Block"  feature that gives the crag its name.  Look for a black streak with bolts.

content.description: The corner left of Trendy Bendy, sharing anchors with that route.
content.location: Right-leaning corner to the right of the large flake, about 200' right of The Block. See photo for Aileron.

content.description:
Not your typical Tuolumne climb.  If you're tired of running it out on glassy slabs and sketchy knobs go get on this thing.  This 20ft roof is super fun and pros up well.  A nice change from de rigueur of Tuolumne.

Was on the cover of the old Tuolumne guide.
content.protection: A few finger and hand size.  Bolts at the belay maybe sketchy.
content.location: Located all by itself up above the Block across from Pywiack.  Look for the roof up and right.

content.description: Game on, rated 10b in an older guide and now rated 10d in the new guides, the bouldery crux of this route still felt hard for the rating. Clipping the second bolt will keep your attention but not as much as clipping the poorly placed 3rd bolt. The climbing remains sustained to the anchor and calling it 10 easy is misleading. A hand size optional piece in the older guide and small optional pro suggested in the Supertopo guide is only recommended if you like carrying extra weight. You could place a hand size piece before the anchor that might hold body weight but would send rock down on your belayer as it ripped out in the event of a fall. You might also get a smaller piece to the left that could hold a fall but you would be blocking what I felt was a crucial undercling hold. While fairly well bolted by TM standards this sport route constantly felt sporty.
content.protection: 5 bolts and 2 closed shuts for an anchor. Also you can get good gear off the ground for a belay anchor to prevent going off the ledge in case the leader falls before clipping the first bolt(recommended).
content.location: This route starts on a ledge several 100 ft rt of the Bunny Slopes. A short awkward bit of climbing(5th class 3rd class) is required to get on the ledge

climbs.name: Aileron
climbs.fa: Greg Barnes, Karin Wuhrmann, Florence Scholl, July 2007.

content.description: A huge flake to the right of The Block has a gaping left side, and a blockier right side. The left side is Grass Roots 10cR, and the right side is Aileron. From the road, the flake looks like a huge fighter jet wing heading towards the lake, hence the name!
content.protection: Thin-4", extra 1.5"-3". Anchor is a slung tree, so might be good to have an extra leaver sling.
content.location: Right of The Block by about 150'.
